title: Female Dancer
description: “Is Nadelman serious?” asked a writer for the New York World in 1919. “Are these things art, or only insolence?” This indignation was sparked by Elie Nadelman’s choice to depict people in contemporary clothing rather than the classical drapery used by most sculptors at the time. Here, the woman’s short dress and high heels evoke modern city life during the Roaring Twenties with whimsy and charm.

publication_history:
Lincoln Kirstein, “Elie Nadelman: Sculptor of the Dance,” Dance Index, vol. 7, no. 6 (1948), 131–51, ill. cover.

Lincoln Kirstein, "Elie Nadelman (1973) p. 296, no. 97, as Standing Female Dancer.
exhibition_history:
Whitney Museum of American Art, The Sculpture and Drawings of Elie Nadelman, 1882–1946, Sept. 23–Nov. 30, 1975, cat. 72; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Dec. 18, 1975–Feb. 15, 1976.

Newark Museum, American Bronze Sculpture, 1850 to the Present, Oct. 18, 1984–Feb. 3, 1985, cat. 52.

San Antonio, Texas, McNay Art Museum, Elie Nadelman: Classical Folk, June 12–Aug. 19, 2001, pl. 16; Pittsburgh, Frick Art and Historical Center, Sept. 21–Dec. 30, 2001, cat. 16.
provenance_text: The artist; by descent in his family; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2016.
